newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: Australia wool group agrees on stockpile sale.
newsitem.headline: Australia wool group agrees on stockpile sale.

text.p: A major section of the Australian wool industry has supported a minimum quarterly release of 90,000 bales of wool from the country's 2.18 million bale stockpile, a statement by Wool Council of Australia (WCA) said.

WCA president Rod Thirkell-Johnston expressed optimism over an industry-wide approach to wool stockpile management after an industry meeting convened by the Australian National Committee (ANC) of the International Wool Textile Organisation.
A more united approach should ensure commitment to industry views by the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy John Anderson, Thirkell-Johnston said.

As well as supporting the 90,000 bale minimum quarterly release, the ANC-convened group supported a target date for completion of the stockpile selldown by December 31, 2000, with the revised programme to start from January 1, 1997.
Agreement was not reached on whether Wool International (WI) should have full commercial flexibility to sell the stockpile or whether a 250,000 bale maximum a quarter should be imposed, he said.
The former Labor government set a fixed quarterly disposal schedule of 182,000-192,000 bales which woolgrowers believe helps to keep auction prices down when the market is weak.

The WCA firmly believed that a cap was not necessary and that WI should assume full commercial responsibility, recognising that it was accountable to its grower shareholders as well as to the government, Thirkell-Johnston said.
He said this view, expressed by all state farm organisations, reflected overwhelming grower sentiment and did not represent an insurmountable difference within the industry.
